The isocontour curves of the steric maps are given in Å. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Schematic reaction mechanism of the first olefin insertion. Graphical abstract A family of three group IV based diamine bis(phenolate) catalysts, [M{2,2ʹ-(OC6H2-4,6-tBu2)2NHC2H4NH}(OiPr)2] (M = Ti (Cat1), Zr (Cat2), and Hf (Cat3)) were synthesized and characterized. These complexes were employed in 1-decene oligomerization using ([Ph3C][B(C6F5)4]) as an activator at 80 °C. NMR spectra of the di(isopropoxy) complexes confirmed C2-symmetrical structures. Cat2 demonstrated the highest activity followed by Cat3 and Cat1, whereas tacticity Cat1>Cat2>Cat3. The origin of this different performance was unveiled by DFT calculations. Interestingly, the increase of oligomerization temperature shifted PDI to the higher values. Moreover, kinetic studies employing population balance approach have been conducted, being outstanding that initiation rate constants were lower than propagation ones by a factor of 100. The precise study of termination reactions by NMR revealed that the significant termination reaction was the creation of two types of unsaturated bonds, i.e. vinylidene and vinylene. The obtained oligomers had viscosity index and pour point values comparable with commercial oils. Keywords Oligomerization Group IV metals ONNO-type ligands 1-Decene Catalyst Kinetic Oil 1 Introduction Oligomerization of higher α-olefins by group IV single-site organometallic complexes has attracted huge attention during the past ten years. Oligomers of higher α-olefin monomers are known as polyalphaolefins (PAO)s which can be used as fragrances, surfactants, adhesives, corrosion protective coatings, and synthetic lubricants (engine oil). Higher α-olefin monomers are usually referred to long olefinic monomers such as 1-hexene, 1-octene, 1-decene, among others [1–5]. An extraordinary class of organometallic catalysts is group IV metal systems based on aryloxide ligands furnished with heteroatom donors (mostly ONNO-based bis(o-aminophenolato) ligands). The aforementioned ligands lead to the tuning of the electronic and steric features of the synthesized complexes [6,7]. Kol and coworkers reported that, for zirconium catalysts, the activity of the complexes and the nature of the synthesized polymers are mostly affected by the mixed information of steric and electronic factors of the substituents on the phenolate rings [8,9]. While bulky ortho substituents tend to isotactic polymerization, electron-withdrawing substituents cause to very high active catalysts, however, with less tacticity and low polymer molecular weight. Theoretical [10–13] and experimental [14–17] investigations on a variety of group IV catalysts with chelating alkoxide ligands have revealed that further electron density on the metal center decreases the insertion barrier energy for an inserting monomer. Furthermore, for a class of titanium bis(phenolate) complexes, it was shown that electron-donating groups in the ligand lead to the increase of catalytic activity [18]. Salan type ligands are another important class of ligands employed in olefin oligomerization and polymerization experiments. All Salan ligands reported to date have featured identical phenolate rings [19]. The feature of the phenolate substituents of the symmetric Salan ligands was discovered to affect strongly the efficiency of the resulting zirconium catalysts in α-olefin polymerization. Thus, electron-withdrawing groups cause to highly active complexes, while bulky substituents cause to slightly active, but highly isospecific complexes [20–23]. Designing new polymerization/oligomerization catalysts is ordinarily performed along with traditional parameters such as catalyst activity, [24–26] average molecular weight (Mn), or molecular weight distribution (MWD); [27–30] meanwhile, these data have limited values for estimation of the polymer’s molecular architecture, i.e. MWD, unsaturated end groups, etc., at various polymerization conditions. However, by using further experimental data, kinetic parameters for various reactions involved in oligomerization can be achieved. Herein, we wish to describe for the first time the synthesis and structural investigation of various group IV catalysts including titanium, zirconium, and hafnium metals with [ONNO] ligand (Scheme 1 ), as well as their catalytic performance in 1-decene oligomerization. The effects of the different metal centers, and various oligomerization parameters on the catalytic productivity and selectivity in 1-decene oligomerization were evaluated experimentally. In addition, the predominant kinetic parameters for Cat1-3 were found and compared with the reported complexes in the literature. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material All experiments including catalyst preparation processes, and also oligomerization reactions were performed under inert atmosphere in glovebox. All used solvents were dried through a solvent purification system (MBraun SPS) and stored over activated molecular sieves in a glovebox prior to use. 3,5-di-tert-buthylcatechole and 1-decene of 94 % purity were provided from Aldrich Chemical Co. (Munich, Germany), then 1-decene was dried by distilling over sodium/benzophenone prior to use. Ethylenediamine was supplied from Sigma-Aldrich Co.(USA), and used without further purification. Titanium tetra(isopropoxide) was provided from Sigma-Aldrich Co.(USA). Zr(OiPr)4(HOiPr) (Aldrich) was used as received. Hafnium tetra(isopropoxide) isopropanol adduct was provided from Sigma-Aldrich Co.(USA). Triphenyl carbenium tetrakis(pentafluorophenyl) borate ([Ph3C][B(C6F5)4]) purchased from Asahi Glass Co., Ltd., was used as received. 2.2 Synthesis of N,N ʹ-bis(2-hydroxy-3,5-di-tert-butylphenyl) ethylene diamine,[L1] Aforementioned ligand was synthesized according to a description method in the literature with a little modification [31]. After removing all impurities by using nitrogen atmosphere, the reactor was charged with freshly distilled 1-decene (10 mL). To this mixture, 4.73 μmol of synthesized catalyst and different quantities of ([Ph3C][B(C6F5)4]) as an activator were added (see Table 1 ). The reaction was started by heating the mixture to pre-determined temperature. After 3 h, the reaction was terminated by injecting acidified solution of MeOH/H2O. Then, the solution was washed three times with 3 wt% solution of NaOH/H2O. The unreacted monomers were extracted by high vacuum (-0.8 bar) and subsequently distillation at 200 °C. 2.7 Quenched NMR scale oligomerization of 1-decene To a catalyst/activator solution in an NMR tube, 1-decene was added. At the desired monomer conversion, this reaction was quenched using 0.25 mL of CD3OD. The quenched reaction was studied as the mentioned methods in the literature [32–34]. 2.8 Characterization High resolution 1H, and 13C-NMR spectra were conducted on Bruker DRX400 MHz NMR spectrometer in deuterated chloroform (CDCl3) for oligomers and in deuterated DMSO for catalysts at 25 °C. The molecular masses and their distributions were examined employing gel permeation chromatography (GPC Agilent 1100). The eluting solvent was THF stabilized with 250 mg/L 2,6-di-tert-butyl-4-methyl phenol with a flow rate of 1 mL/min. Polystyrene standards were used for calibration. Initiation, propagation, and termination kinetics were measured by automated quench-flow technique as previously described [32–34]. Mass spectra were obtained on a JEOL JMS-700. Kinematic viscosity (KV) values at 40 and 100 °C were measured in centistokes (cSt) according to the ASTM D445 test method. Using these two viscosities, viscosity index (VI) was determined by an empirically derived procedure described in ASTM D2270. Pour point values of synthesized oligomers were measured according to ASTM D 97. 2.9 Computational details All density functional theory calculations were performed with the Gaussian 16 set of programs [35]. The electronic configuration of the molecular systems was described with the pure functional of Becke and Perdew (BP86 keyword in Gaussian 16); [36,37] using the SDD ECP on Ti, Zr and Hf, [38,39] while the split-valence plus one polarization function SVP basis set on all main group atoms during geometry optimizations [40]. Since corrections due to dispersion are essential to study the reactivity, [41,42] we have included them through the D3 Grimme’s method (GD3 keyword in Gaussian) [43]. The geometry optimizations were performed without symmetry constraints and the characterization of the local stationary points was carried out by analytical frequency calculations. These frequencies were used to calculate unscaled zero-point energies (ZPEs) as well as thermal corrections and entropy effects at 80 °C and 1 atm. We obtained the energies by single-point calculations on the optimized geometries with the hybrid PBE0 functional of Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE1PBE keyword in Gaussian), [44,45] and the Valence triple-zeta polarization basis set DEF2-TZVP for increased accuracy [46,47]. Solvent effects were included with the Solvation Model based on Density (SMD), [48] using toluene as a solvent. The reported Gibbs free energies in this work are electronic energies obtained at the PBE0-D3/Def2TZVP∼sdd(SMD)//BP86-D3/SVP∼sdd level of theory corrected with zero-point energies, thermal corrections and entropy effects evaluated at 80 °C and 1 atm. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of complexes A series of [ONNO]-based ligands was synthesized (Scheme 1). Reaction of tetra(isopropoxide) derivatives of Ti, Zr, and Hf with 1 eq of ligand (L1) in aforementioned solvent readily yields di(isopropoxy) complexes [49]. The NMR data of the resulted catalysts are strongly related to those previously reported of their Ti analogue [50]. The NMR data for compounds 1–3 confirmed their effective C2-symmetric structure (see supporting information, Fig S1-S6) [31]. It has been accepted that existence of bulky ortho substituents leads to the C2-symmetrical structure [50]. 3.2 Oligomerization behavior of the synthesized catalysts Results of 1-decene oligomerization with aforementioned catalysts using ([Ph3C][B(C6F5)4]) cocatalyst have been gathered in Table 1. According to represented results, Zr-based catalyst was found to be slightly more reactive as oligomerization catalyst in the presence of the same cocatalyst: the addition of 4.73 μmol of Cat2 and 1.0 eq of cocatalyst to pure 1-decene at the temperature of 80 °C gives 6.80 g of oligomer after 180 min, which exhibits an activity of 479 g (oligomer)/mmolcat.h, that is 0.73 and 1.32 % higher than analogous hafnium and titanium catalysts, respectively. Polymerization activity of higher olefins by group IV single-site organometallic complexes does not preferentially conform the metallocene polyethylene activity trends [51]. Group IV[OSSO] bis(phenolato)/(B(C6F5)3) catalysts resulted 1-hexene activity orders of Ti > Zr>Hf, [52] whereas group IV [ONNO] Salan/B(C6F5)3 catalysts have shown 1-hexene activity orders of Zr > Ti≈Hf [53]. Kol and coworkers have demonstrated that diamine bis(phenolate) catalysts with zirconium active center had the activity of 2-fold comparison to titanium analogue in 1-hexene polymerization [54]. According to collected data in Table 1, molecular weight of synthesized oligomers has a close relationship with employed metal center and has the order of Ti>Hf > Zr, meanwhile for Ti, Hf, and Zr-based catalysts (Cat1, Cat3, and Cat2), average molecular weight (Mn) is determined as high as 601, 482, and 444 g/mol, respectively (see Fig. 1 a). Obtained molecular weight trend is according to the reduced termination/propagation proportions of synthesized complexes (see kinetic section; Table 3) [9,55]. Oligomerization of 1-hexene with amine bis(phenolate) complexes had been shown that Hf-based complexes produced lower molecular weight oligomers related to similar Zr-based ones, [54] which confirms our obtained trend. In order to investigate the influence of metal center on molecular weight distribution and living behavior of produced oligomers, polydispersity index (PDI) values were examined. The identified molecular weight distributions by employing GPC analysis were monomodal, and the obtained quantities were in the range of 1.13 − 1.30. Surprisingly, the three complexes initiated living 1-decene oligomerization behavior and furnished narrow polydispersity, however this manner showed weakly the trend of Hf > Ti > Zr (see Table 1). In fact, recorded PDI values were 1.28, 1.19, and 1.15 for Hf, Ti, and Zr- based catalysts, respectively [56]. Generally Cat2 with M = Zr produced lower molecular weight and narrower molecular weight distribution related to Ti, and Hf-based complexes. Oligomerization of 1-decene at 80 and 120 °C for 180 min yielded oligomers with extremely narrow polydispersity (see Table 1, entries 1 and 4). The dependence of the molecular weight values upon the oligomerization temperature together with the narrow PDI values confirms that the oligomerization proceeds in a living manner under the mentioned conditions (Fig. 1c). As it is obvious from Table 1 results, the increasing of oligomerization temperature from 80 to 120 °C, the molecular weight value decreased to 480 g/mol and the PDI value increased and moved to higher values. Similar results have been observed in polymerization of propylene with titanium catalysts by Yue-Sheng Li [57,58]. In order to experimentally validate the activator/catalyst (A/C) ratio on molecular weight distribution of the obtained oligomers, oligomerization reactions were carried out with different A/C ratios and collected results are shown in Fig. 1b and Fig. 2 [59–61]. According to depicted GPC curves, the increase of A/C ratio forces the PDI to expand and shifts slightly to the higher quantities. For A/C ratios of 0.25, 0.5, 1.0, and 1.5 mol/mol, obtained molecular weight distributions were 1.13, 1.17, 1.19, and 1.19, respectively. However, the higher the activator content the lesser the influence on Mn and PDI values of the synthesized oligomers is (see Fig. 2). Abu-Omar and coworkers, when used substoichiometric amounts of activator in the oligomerization of 1-hexene with Zr[tBu-ONTHFO]Bn2 catalyst system, observed that the molecular weight distribution in the substoichiometric cases interestingly moves toward lower values (becomes narrower) [62]. Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations at the PBE0-D3/Def2TZVP∼sdd(SMD)//BP86-D3/SVP∼sdd level [63], were carried out to unveil why Cat2 shows higher activity with respect to Cat1 and Cat3. Using the methyl moiety as chain in the cationic catalytic active species we conducted studies to distinguish which is the nature of the metal catalyst and its affinity towards entering olefins. No electronic trend could support the experimental results with Parr electrophilicity values of 0.911, 0.737 and 0.657 for Cat1-Cat3 series [64,65]. Whereas geometrically the nature of the metal turned out to be fundamental. Despite the identical ligands for Cat1-Cat3, structurally first the MC is significantly weaker for the Zr and Hf based catalysts, with Mayer Bond Orders (MBO) [66] lower by 0.173 and 0.124 with respect to the Ti one, respectively [67,68]. Thus, this demonstrates why Cat2 is more active than Cat1 and slightly more than Cat3. The bite angle (OMO) follows the same trend with values of 121.8, 125.7 and 124.7° for Cat1-Cat3, respectively [69,70]. Thus, the metal center for the Ti based catalyst is the most impeded, which does not facilitate the attack of the olefin. And for the sake of consistency, steric maps based on %VBur were performed to validate this latter hypothesis (see Fig. 3 ). The maps were calculated at 2 Å away from the metal where the entering olefin would interact [71–73]. The %VBur differentiated those catalysts, with occupations of 53.1 % for Cat1 to be compared with 51.0 and 51.9 % for Cat2 and Cat3, respectively. Further, looking at the quadrants, the %VBur for Cat1 is lower for the two most crowded ones (in average 53.8 % with respect to 55.6 % for the other two catalysts), thus the metal center of Cat1 is more equally occupied [74,75], and thus, its cleft does not facilitate the interaction with the olefin substrate in the other ones [76,77]. For the sake of consistency, the first insertion of 1-propene was calculated (see Fig. 4 ), and confirmed the above trend, thermodynamically (1.7, -4.3 and -2.8 kcal/mol), and also kinetically (15.3, 11.0 and 11.8 kcal/mol) for Cat1-Cat3, respectively. 3.3 Structural study of the synthesized oligomers Microstructure of the synthesized 1-decene oligomers was explored using NMR spectroscopy based on the literature data [78,79]. In this line, to identify the configurational arrangement of 1-decene structure in the oligo1-decene backbone, the side chain methylene carbon (C3 in Fig. 5 ) was examined as the most sensitive carbon nuclei of pendant group toward stereo-regularity (the 13C-NMR spectra of the samples were shown in Fig S16-S19 of the supporting information) [79,80,81]. 13C-NMR spectra of methyl region of oligo(1-decene)s produced with Cat1-3 at the mentioned conditions were shown in Fig. 5. According to the summary of results in Table 2 , Ti-based catalyst yielded oligomers with higher tacticity (mm + rr) of 88.5 % relative to the corresponding Zr and Hf-based catalysts (87.3 and 86.8 %). Moreover, in order to investigate the influence of oligomerization temperature on the microstructures of synthesized oligomers, the produced samples by Ti-based catalyst at 80 and 120 °C were considered (entries 1 and 4). Calculations showed that, by increasing temperature, tacticity decreased. Mashima and coworkers reported that low polymerization temperature affords poly(1-hexene) with higher isotacticity [82]. We assumed that the stereo-errors arise from chain epimerization reactions and not from enantiofacial misinsertion, since variation of polymerization temperature did affect the degree of isotacticity. These results differ from the obtained results from metallocene catalysts [83]. On the other hand, regioselectivity is another crucial factor in oligomerization of olefins, which affects the structure of the produced oils. Many academic validations have been performed to design new catalytic systems, to better control of regioselectivity in higher olefin polymerization/oligomerization. Different types of unsaturated structures can be formed in the produced 1-decene oligomers: vinylidene, CH2=CRRʹ (Vd, between 4.7 and 4.8 ppm); vinyl, CH2= CHR (Vn, 4.9 and 5.6 ppm); trisubstituted vinylene, RCH = CRʹRʹʹ (3Vn, 5.2 ppm); and disubstituted vinylene, RCH = CHRʹ (2Vn, between 5.3 and 5.5 ppm) [79]. Scheme 2 shows the possible unsaturated structures in 1-decene oligomers. The 1H-NMR spectrum of the obtained oligomers by Cat1-3 (Fig. 6 ) disclosed unsaturated end groups signals. In the spectra, we could not find related vinyl groups’ chemical shifts. It had been shown that vinylidene unsaturated structure is the result of termination reaction after a 1,2 insertion. However, termination process after 2,1 insertion furnishes vinylene unsaturation [84]. Table 2 clearly discloses the variation of each unsaturated structure by increasing temperature for the synthesized oligomers. By focusing on summarized results, produced unsaturated units are completely temperature-sensitive, where vinylidene, and vinylene unsaturated contents are predominant at higher, and lower temperatures, respectively. Moreover, according to collected 1H-NMR spectra results in Table 2, we have found that the type of the unsaturated structures is strongly affected by the nature of metal center in the synthesized catalysts, too. For example, by utilizing Cat1 as complex, with M = Ti, the produced oligomers showed 1,2-regioselectivity of 22.1 %, while 11.2 %, and 25.6 % for the systems with M = Zr, and Hf, respectively. Lu and coworkers developed highly active regioselective 1-hexene polymerization catalysts by employing tridentate [ONO] ligands. According to the authors, high regioselectivity was obtained when Zr was replaced with Ti as a metal center [56]. The NMR spectra of synthesized oligo(1-decene)s are consistent with a linear structure containing unsaturated alkyl chain-end groups of an n-octyl type (see Supporting Information, Figures S16-S23). 3.4 Kinetic studies of oligomerization reaction catalyzed by synthesized catalysts In order to design catalysts’ structure, identifying kinetic factors and subsequently obtaining rate constants for oligomerization reaction is substantial criterion in rationalizing quantitative structure-activity relationships, which correlate rate constants to complexes’ structure. In this part of study, the kinetic of 1-decene oligomerization using a series of synthesized catalysts was investigated. Generally, by employing various experimental techniques, kinetic parameters for various reactions involved in oligomerization can be determined. Initiation, [85,86] and propagation [86,87,88] rate constants have been calculated by determining rate of monomer consumption/oligomer production. Measuring vinyl unsaturated contents [89,90] or degree of oligomerization [86,91,92] has been reported for the determination of chain transfer rate. The approach we employed to formulate a kinetic-based model to illustrate the oligomerization data, [93] for each catalyst system, consists of the determination of a kinetic modeling method analyzing (1) monomer consumption, (2) active site contents, and (3) unsaturated end group contents during the oligomerization reaction. Scheme 3 describes the elementary kinetic steps of the 1-decene oligomerization. Over the temperature range of 30 °C, initiation rate constant (ki) increases linearly with [monomer]: [32] (1) ∂ 1 * ∂ t = k i [ 1 ] [ 1 - d e c e n e ] where, [1]= concentration of catalyst, and [1*] = concentration of the primary active catalyst. The catalyst participation was calculated from the active site counting techniques (quench with CD3OD followed by 1H-NMR analysis of oligomer chains, see Figures S24-S26 of supporting information). In the 1H-NMR spectra, both primary and secondary metal alkyls were detected. Deep examination of Table 3 results shows that initiation rate constant (ki) for Cat2 is bigger than in Cat1 and Cat3, and interestingly observed trend for ki values was exactly inversely related to the molecular weight. By comparing results from Tables 1 and 3 it can be concluded that catalyst with high initiation rate constant value produces oligomers with low molecular weight, meaning that high contents of active centers in the reaction media leads to the formation of more oligomer chains with low molecular weight. Oligomerization was performed at 30, 90, 120, and 180 min with constant 1-decene concentration. A traditional set of data is illustrated in Fig. 7 , with the 1-decene consumption plotted vs the oligomerization time. Since the propagation rate was unaffected by the addition of further cocatalyst (1.5 equiv of [Ph3C][B(C6F5)4] per M), we stabilized Eq. 2 for determining propagation rate constant (kp). (2) ∂ [ 1 - d e c e n e ] ∂ t = k p 1 * 1 - d e c e n e Validation of calculated rate constants values exhibits that initiation rate constants are less than propagation ones for all three synthesized complexes. Obtained propagation rate constants followed the order of Ti > Hf > Zr for the aforementioned catalysts. It can be concluded that the difference in propagation rate constants in three synthesized catalysts is because of the electronic nature in the used metal centers [94]. According to accepted coordinative polymerization reaction mechanism, propagation step can be terminated by chain transfer reactions. These reactions are urgent, since we observed oligomer chains with unsaturated end groups. Rate of vinylidene formation is independent of [1-decene], and the rate of vinylene formation is first order in monomer concentration [32]. According to Eq.3, and also by employing pristine calculated rate constants for initiation (ki), the kvinylidene and kvinylene were calculated. Notably, this result reveals that kvinylene is bigger than kvinylidene by the factor of 2−10. By using kinetic factors we can estimate the tendency of synthesized catalysts toward 1-decene oligomerization to yield longer or shorter oligomers (see Eq. 4). (3) ∂ [ e n d g r o u p ] ∂ t = k t 1 0 t + 1 k i 1 - d e c e n e 0 e - k i 1 - d e c e n e 0 t - 1 k i 1 - d e c e n e 0 (4) P r o p v s t e r m r a t e 1,2 - i n s r a t e 1 , 2 - t e r m ≈ k p C * [ M ] k v i n y l d e n e C * = k p [ M ] k v i n y l d e n e where, [M] = [1-decene] and [C*] = concentration of the primary active catalyst. According to Eq. 4, kp/kvinylidene value is representative of synthesized oligomers’ length. By validation of calculated results it can be found that Cat1 with M = Ti, in comparison to Cat2 and Cat3, produces longer oligomer chains, which is a confirmation of GPC results (see Table 1). In order to determine percent of misinserted monomers that inserted into a primary polymer unit, Eq.5 was introduced. (5) % m i s i n s e r t i o n ≈ 2,1 - i n s a l l i n s ≈ C * M K m i s C * M ( K p + K m i s ) = K m i s K p + K m i s where, [M] = [1-decene], and [C*] = concentration of primary active catalyst. Calculated % misinsertion results of synthesized oligomers for each catalyst sample were summarized in Table 3. Deep examination of Table 3 results unveiled that the rates of misinsertion for all synthesized complexes are lower than propagation rate. Interestingly, Zr, and Hf-based catalysts showed higher and lower degree of % misinsertion, respectively. Similar results have been reported by Busico and coworkers [86]. The specific kinetic features of employed catalytic system are as follows: (1) Catalyst participation is around 40–60 %. (2) Initiation rate is relatively lower compared to propagation rate (Table 2). (3) Ti-based catalyst system showed higher propagation rate in comparison to Zr-, and Hf-based catalysts. (4) Chain transfer reactions involve both monomer dependent and monomer independent pathways, which include β-H transfer to monomer, and β-H elimination reactions, respectively. In all three systems, kvinylene is higher than kvinylidene, which is an indication that high fractions of chain termination reactions take place through β-H transfer to monomer mechanism. (5) There is an impressive variation in the end group natures when the oligomerization temperature is allowed to increase (Table 2). (6) Reduction of termination/propagation proportions of synthesized complexes showed a direct proportion to oligomers’ molecular weight of catalyst systems. Ongoing calculations are on the way to validate the above experimental results. 3.5 Kinematic viscosity (KV) at 40 and 100 °C and pour point of the synthesized oligomers High-quality engine oil should have moderate viscosity at low temperatures, which is necessary for a safe "cold start" of the engine. The reliability of engine oil at low temperatures is characterize in terms of the pour point and kinematic viscosity at 40, and 100 °C. It was found that the pour point and viscosity index (VI) values of oligomers strongly depend on the architecture of the constituent hydrocarbons. According to Table 4 several important conclusions can be obtained from viscosity results: i) Obtained oligomers from Cat2 resulted low-viscosity oils (KV100 3.2 cSt) in comparison to oligomers from Cat1 and Cat3 under the same conditions. However, produced oils using different catalysts show comparable VIs (in the range 124.6–154.9). This can be explained by the 1H-NMR results, which indicate that all PAO products have a very consistent branch ratio [95,96]. ii) The viscosity of the PAO product also decreased with increasing oligomerization temperature to 120 ℃ (runs1 and 4 in Table 4). iii) Increasing A/C ratio led to an enhancement in kinematic viscosity of oils. In fact, high loading of activator can improve catalytic activity in 1-decene oligomerization (see Table 1), and therefore, the PAO product with a high degree of oligomerization and a high kinematic viscosity can be obtained. Table 4 results also show the pour point data for synthesized oligomers. It is obvious that pour point values were in the range of -45 to −67 °C, which is conventional for PAO lubricants. Furthermore, prepared oil in run 4 has the lowest pour point, may be due to it is high atactic nature (see NMR results, Table 2) [97–99]. It was found that long-chain branched hydrocarbons are known by low pour points, in general, side chains improve the viscosity index and decreases the pour point values [97]. The GC results of synthesized oligomers are gathered in Table 4. In order to investigate the influence of metal center on oligomer fraction percentages, and according to collected GC results in Table 4, we deduced that the percentage of tetramers follows the trend of Ti>Hf > Zr for synthesized catalysts. These results were an emphasis on molecular weight trends of produced oligomers, which had exactly the same trend with metal centers. 4 Conclusions Three group IV based diamine bis(phenolate) catalysts were synthesized and fully characterized by elemental analysis and NMR spectroscopy. We indicated that synthesized complexes cause to a remarkable correlation of molecular weight, molecular weight distribution, and tacticity in 1-decene oligomerization by using [Ph3C][B(C6F5)4] as cocatalyst. Then, we proposed a mechanism for each catalyst system by using kinetic parameters and rate constants which derived from the kinetic evaluation section. Aforementioned mechanism disclosed that oligomerization of 1-decene proceeds via lower initiation rate compared to the propagation one. Suggested mechanism also included monomer misinsertion and involved two main chain transfer pathways, too. Each of these steps can be affected by employed metal centers and oligomerization conditions. The catalytic performance was evaluated with density functional theory which disclosed why the catalytic activity seems to follow the trend Zr>Hf>>Ti. However, the differences are too loo to be quantitative. The molecular weight results of produced oligomers which had been studied by GPC were strongly confirmed with GC analysis. Viscosity index values of synthesized oligomers were more than 124, while measured pour point values were less than -45 °C, which were comparable with the characteristic data of commercial ones obtained from BF3 catalyst system. coredata.dc:description: A family of three group IV based diamine bis(phenolate) catalysts, [M{2,2ʹ-(OC6H2-4,6-tBu2)2NHC2H4NH}(OiPr)2] (M = Ti (Cat1), Zr (Cat2), and Hf (Cat3)) were synthesized and characterized. These complexes were employed in 1-decene oligomerization using ([Ph3C][B(C6F5)4]) as an activator at 80 °C. NMR spectra of the di(isopropoxy) complexes confirmed C2-symmetrical structures. Cat2 demonstrated the highest activity followed by Cat3 and Cat1, whereas tacticity Cat1>Cat2>Cat3. The origin of this different performance was unveiled by DFT calculations. Interestingly, the increase of oligomerization temperature shifted PDI to the higher values. Moreover, kinetic studies employing population balance approach have been conducted, being outstanding that initiation rate constants were lower than propagation ones by a factor of 100. The precise study of termination reactions by NMR revealed that the significant termination reaction was the creation of two types of unsaturated bonds, i.e. vinylidene and vinylene. The obtained oligomers had viscosity index and pour point values comparable with commercial oils.
coredata.dc:title: Group IV diamine bis(phenolate) catalysts for 1-decene oligomerization
